entry.title: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
In the realm of software development and maintenance, the practice of ceasing support for vulnerable or outdated systems is a widely accepted norm. This concept is pivotal for maintaining the security and efficiency of digital platforms. Notably, several major projects and operating systems exemplify this approach by setting predefined end-of-life (EOL) dates for their versions. For instance, Bitcoin Core adheres to an 18-month support cycle, ensuring that users transition to more secure and updated versions within a reasonable timeframe. Similarly, Ubuntu offers long-term support (LTS) for its releases for a duration of five years, providing a stable and secure environment for its users over an extended period. Windows also follows this principle by offering unpaid support for its products for five years, encouraging users to upgrade to newer versions for continued security and feature updates.
The discussion extends into the feasibility of allowing addresses to sign with their keys as a proof of life and possession in scenarios where updates are not adopted, highlighting a technical possibility yet expressing skepticism regarding the motivation to implement such functionality. The underlying concern revolves around the practicality and willingness of communities and developers to support mechanisms that allow outdated or vulnerable software to persist without participating in essential updates.
For further details on the support timelines of various software, [endoflife.date](https://endoflife.date/) provides comprehensive information, illustrating the widespread adoption of the practice across different platforms and technologies. This resource serves as a valuable reference for understanding the lifecycle management policies of numerous projects and operating systems, reinforcing the importance of timely updates and support cessation as critical components of digital ecosystem stewardship.
